titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: The Corner stone, of the Smithsonian Edifice, was laid— I did not attend to witness it— We called at Coleman’s, to visit Mrs. George Parkman, her son, and daughter, but they were out and we left cards— I walked partly home from the Capitol—and walked again after dinner— Elizabeth. C. Adams left us, and went to Mrs. Campbells— I received from the Commissioner of Pensions, a Pension Certificate, for the heirs of Peter Dunbar. and enclosed it to Mr. Ellis Dedham—

Heard Mr. Morrison, at the Unitarian Church, preach from Matthew 6.25—“Is not the life, more than meat, and the body than raiment.” And after dinner, at St John’s Church heard the Revd. Mr. Tillinghast. from Gallatians 6.14—“But God forbid, that I should glory save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ—by whom the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world.” I was much pleased with this Discourse— One of Mr. Pyne’s children died this morning. Mrs. Goods daughter, Jane, was married in Church this afternoon, after the evening service, to an Englishman named Mellon—

I took to the Pension Office, a certificate received from Mr. Jonathan Wild, that his mother Deborah Wild, is yet living—which certificate is necessary to obtain her Claim for a Pension— Mrs. Parkman and her son, visited us last evening and left this morning for Baltimore— Her daughter, is in very delicate health, and was too unwell to come out— This excursion to the South, is principally occasioned by the state of her health— Mr. Frye was here this evening, and left with me, his account current, as my Agent and Attorney from the 28th. June 1844. to the 18th. of April 1847. presenting a nominal balance to be accounted for in my favor, of $281,74 cents, with a note stating that this balance is altogether nominal as there are outstanding liabilities against him to a much greater amount. Such as Taxes, that have become due since the last were paid— Indispensable repairs, on property, expenses of collections, including the fees and commissions of Lawyers, Marshalls, Clerks of Courts, Magistrates, Constables, and collectors and sundry small incidental expenses necessarily incurred by him, not heretofore charged in any accounts since the commencement of his Agency for me, on the 18th. of May 1835. This statement is furnished me for the purpose only of informing me, of the monies actually

received and the principal expenditures, made during the period embraced in it, And it presents a picture of real Estate, consisting of dwelling houses, and Mills, which cost upwards of $30,000 proving, if not an absolute burden, scarcely a perceptible profit— My own house rent, clogged with continual expenses of repairs, is the only profit, I have derived, from my large real Estate, in the City of Washington—which has cost me, at least one hundred thousand dollars.
I did not notice, that Mr. John P. Kennedy of Baltimore, was here, last Friday— The following is a copy of a Letter from me to Mr. Frye, dated Washington 28. Novr. 1837—
Nathaniel Frye. Esqr. Washington

Among the papers in the bundle, which Mrs. Adams had left with you, and which she brought back the day before yesterday, I have found the obligation of Johnson Hellen to his sister, but not the certificate of Stock in the Bank of Washington. Mrs. Adams has taken Johnson’s obligation, and will send a deliver it to you—

But there are missing from the bundle all the Deeds of the Columbian Mills, and the plot of the land with them— Last Spring when I went home I separated my Deeds of property here from those of property in Massachusetts, taking the last home with me, and leaving the others here— That is the bundle which Mrs. Adams left with you. In making the separation I may accidentally have put up the Deeds of the Columbian Mills, with the Massachusetts vouchers, which I left with my Son— I will write to him to enquire— I did write to him to ascertain if the obligation of Johnson Hellen and the certificate of Stock in the Washington Bank were not there— He answered they were not— Happily Johnson’s Obligation is now found— The certificate is still missing—
Affectionately yours
The Original of this Letter is returned to Mr. Frye—

Mr. Lewis Johnson was here yesterday, and left with me two Letters, for Mr. John Otis of West-Barnstable, to be forwarded by the mail— I was at the Franklin Insurance Company Office, and received a Dividend of 7 1/2 per cent for the half year and left there, a note of $4000, to Mrs. Mary. C. Adams, endorsed by her, instead of one, for the same sum, dated the 21st. of March 1827, to William. S. Nichols, taken up and cancelled— A security contingent note on two hundred shares of the Stock standing to my credit, on the Books of the Company. The responsibility of the whole note being upon me, and my property— Mary Louisa dined at Mrs. Swift’s being the Birth day of Miss Howard of Springfield— Capt Casey was here this evening— His sister Miss Casey sent me a bouquet of flowers. I received from the Committee of Arrangements, an invitation to witness the display of fire works, at the illumination next Saturday

Mr. Gramer was here, and spoke of the movement. to displace him as the President of the Directors of the Franklin Insurance Company—which I assured him I should not countenance—or support— I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis, $471,63 cents, being the discount on $450, Virginia Bank Bills paid me yesterday together with 25 dollars in Patriotic Bank bills, and 12 cents in change for the half yearly Dividend— Isaac Hull Adams, and Lieut Joseph. Harrod. Adams. returned from Norfolk. Elizabeth. C. Adams, left us for some days, and went to Mrs. Campbell’s— I had visits from John Spear Smith of Baltimore and from Mr. Archibald Campbell with Prof Joseph Henry. L.L.D. Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, who conversed in a very edifying manner upon the proposed management of that Establishment, Sunk as I have always apprehended it would be, into a nest of jobs for literary and Political Adventurers— I received from the Commissioner of Pensions, two widow’s pension certificates in favor of Deborah Wild. of Braintree, Massachusetts— Received evening
visits from Mr. Richard Rush with his daughter Julia— He has come to Washington for his instructions upon his new mission as minister to France— Mary Louisa and my two nephews, Isaac Hull, and Lieut Joseph. H. Adams, went to the May Ball. Mrs. Goods, who from the time Mrs. Fader went away, has been my nurse, was taken very sick last night, and disabled for attendance on me.

I enclosed to Mr. Jonathan Wild, the two Widow’s Pension Certificates, for his mother Deborah Wild of Braintree and answered, the invitation to witness the Fire works on Saturday, which I declined, on account of my health— Dr. Thomas was here, having been several days himself detained by indisposition— Mrs. Goods continues confined to her room— We had evening visits, from Mr. and Mrs. Seaton— Morning ride to the Navy Yard and afternoon walk till sun set— Mr. Kavasales, stationed as a Navy Chaplain at the Navy Yard, in this City, called here to see me two or three days since—

Mrs. Goods, has recovered, though I this morng rose from bed and dressed myself without assistance, which I perhaps, shall never do again—being a complete cripple, for the remnant of my days— Elizabeth— C. Adams returned from Mrs. Campbell’s. I gave a check, for one hundred dollars, to Mrs. Mary C. Adams, on account of Household expenses—and received myself, the money at the Bank, in five dollar Bills— I walked before dinner, and rode after dinner, with the Ladies, until about sunset— The news came, of a famous victory by General Scott, near Jalapa, on the 18th. of the last month. I have ceased making fire in my bed chamber— We read in the evening, several chapters, in Walpole’s Memoirs, of the reign of George the third—

Day of rejoicing for the victories— Cannonade and ringing of bells, in the morning.— Walk round the Patent Office Building before dinner, and ride round Meridian Hill, towards Sunset. Major Graham, Mr. Whipple and Mr. Reynolds, paid us morning visits— Illumination and the Fire works in the evening for sundry victories, to which was added that of Cerro Gordo on the 18th. of last month

Heard this morning at the Unitarian Church, Mr. Bellows from Massachusetts. A brother, of the gentleman of the Same name from New York— His Discourse was from Matthew 9.17. “Neither do men put new wine into old bottles, else the bottles break and the wine runneth and the bottles perish; but they put new wine into new bottles and both are preserved.” Mr. Bellows, is a Sensible preacher, though not equal to his brother. In the afternoon, at St John’s Church Mr. Pyne read the evening Service, for the fifth Sunday after Easter, but instead of a Sermon, delivered an Address to the children, of his Congregation, which I did not stay to hear— He had administered the Communion in the morning, and is in deep affliction, at the loss of his daughter— We had evening visits in Succession from Mr. Glück and Lieut Thom. I received three Quarterly accounts current, from the 1st: July 1846; to the 31st. March 1847. from my son—bringing up, my Family and household recounts, to the present time, in addition to those which are constantly kept by us here— On my Son’s last account, there is a balance of $139.50 cents, due to him on the 31st. of March last—

I received this day, a Letter for my wife, from Miss M. S. Hughes,
daughter of Mr. Christopher Hughes. in answer to enquiries, concerning her Father’s illness. It is dated on Saturday, and mentions that he is now convalescent. A Letter from Samuel. H. Davis, dated Peoria Illinois, containing some particulars, relating to the Presidential Election, of 1801. He says the circumstances are all detailed, in the Winchester Virginia Republican, in 1832. the author of which he thinks is the Revd. William Hill D.D. A Presbyterian Minister, extensively and deservedly, known in that Church. and he thinks, that a line from me, addressed to this Dr. William Hill at Winchester would doubtless receive instant attention— This Mr. Davis, informs me that he is the brother of the Architect, in New York, consulted last year by my Son, upon my project, for building at Mount Wollaston, a Library Fire Proof for the preservation of my Books, and papers, and those of my Father— I received also a singular Letter from A. S. Todd, dated at Wheeling the 28th. of April last, enquiring, with some degree of formality, my opinion, with regard to the comparitive healthiness, or unhealthiness, of Air, heated by Furnaces, in the Cellar, or basement, of a house, over that heated, by common Fire places— He alleges, that he is building a large and expensive house, at Wheeling, and that his enquiries, are instigated, by the diversities of opinion, which he finds among his friends, on this subject— I took a ride and walk before dinner. Mr. Thom was here this evening, and brought us a sample of Mexican Chapparal— We finished reading of Walpole’s Memoirs, of the first ten years, of the reign of George III— They are not very interesting, as they close, precisely at the time, when the contest between Great Britain and her North American Colonies, become of transcendent importance, to the History of this Country— They relate almost entirely, to the personal intrigues, of the Earl of Chatham the Earl of Bute, the Bedford, and Grenville families, Duke of
Grafton, and Marquis of Rockingham. A period of darkness, with which, the only rays of light that pierced the gloom radiate from the mind of Edmund Burke—

I answered the Letter from Samuel H. Davis of Peoria Illinois relating to the Presidential Election of 1801. and wrote also to my Son acknowledging the receipt of his three Quarterly accounts, from the first of July 1846, to the thirty-first of March 1847— I took no other exercise than a ride in the Carriage, towards Evening—

I rode to the Capitol, intending to return to the Library the four Volumes of Walpole’s Memoirs of George III. but the Library was not open— I left the books therefore, in the care of Mr. Buck one of the Clerks, in the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives, B. B. French— Mr. French, has risen to the Office of Clerk of the House, after being several years, a subordinate Officer, in it— He is a Democrat, but an excellent Officer— Mr. Buck is one of the subalterns, introduced by McNulty and also very attentive to his duty, and very obliging— Miss Mary Cutts dined with us—

I received a Letter from William Ellis Dedham, Massachusetts, dated the 8th. May, acknowledging the receipt of the Pension Certificate, in favor of the heirs of Relief Dunbar, highly acceptable, as it came quite unexpectedly—after a long and persevering pursuit the final success of which, was owing
to his indefatigable perseverance— I rode to the Capitol and found the Volumes of Walpole’s Memoirs were returned to the Library, from which I took out, the five Volumes of Crocker’s edition of Boswell’s Life of Samuel Johnson— During the recess of Congress the Library is open only three days in the week Tuesday’s, Thursday’s and Saturday’s, but the Librarian Mr. Mehan told me that they were in attendance there every day, except on Sundays. I received this day a notification from E. Y. Pope, Secretary of a Prudential Committee, dated South Braintree May 7th. 1847—in the following terms—

At our Society meeting you were chosen, one of the Board of Visitors, for the Horace, Institute, and an examination, of the Students of the Horace Institute will take place, on May 11th. at 1 oclock P.M. and you are respectfully invited to attend, as one, of the Board of Visitors— The singular part, of this matter is, that I know not what the Horace Institute is, and can only conjecture that it is an incorporated School or Academy, in the Town of Braintree— The time of the Meeting being past, before I received this notification, it seems useless for me to answer it.

Mr. White of Philadelphia son of the late Bishop White, paid me a morning visit— I rode this morning to the Navy Yard, stopping at Miss Casey’s lodgings, to return some English Newspapers which she had lent me— I took a short walk in the afternoon, but finding it from day to day, more difficult to walk, fear that I must henceforth, confine all my bodily exercise, to riding in a carriage. I answered the Letter of Mr. Ellis of Dedham— We commenced in the evening, reading the Life of Johnson.

I received from Moses McClean, late member of Congress from the fifteenth Congressional District of Pennsylvania, a card, advertising himself as Attorney at Law, Gettysburg Pennsylvania, and announcing that having withdrawn from Political life, he will devote his attention hereafter exclusively to the practise of his profession and that all Claims Sent to him for collection, will receive prompt attention. The Card concludes with references to sundry well known Political men, of New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore— I received also a Letter from A. S. Todd, of Wheeling asking my opinion, with regard to the healthiness of heating house by Furnaces— I went with Major Graham, to the Office of the Commissioner for Drawing the Boundary Line between the British Possessions, and the United States. at the North-east, conformably to the Ashburton Treaty I examined several of the maps, executed under this Commission and agreed with Major Graham, to examine them further, in the course of next week— Albert Smith of Maine, is the Commissioner on the Part of the United States, and Colonel Estcourt, is the principal agent on the part of Great Britain. We took a ride this afternoon— Captain Casey spent the evening with us—

At the Unitarian Church heard Mr. Bellows, preach from 1. Corinthians 2.9. “Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him.” and at St Johns Church in the afternoon, two other Clergymen were in the Pulpit with Mr. Pyne. Mr. Lyle from New York, read the Service, from the Sunday after Ascension day, and a Mr. Sneed preached, from, John 5, and the first part of the 39th. verse, Search the Scriptures— Evening visits from Miss Mary E. E. Cutts, and Lieut. George Thom—

At twelve oclock, I went with Major Graham to the Office of the Commissioners, for settling the Boundary between Great Britain and the United States, according to the Ashburton Treaty— I inspected about sixty sheets, of the map, upon which they had drawn, the line of partition and which has been executed with great precision—

I received from Dr. Thomas Miller a written notification, that at one oclock P.M. tomorrow the Surveyor of the City, at his request would run and ascertain the lines, between our adjoining property, that is to say the dividing Lots in Number 16, and Number 17. in Square No 253, in the City of Washington.

at one oclock P.M. I met Dr. Thomas Miller and the City Surveyor Randolph Coyle, on the spot, of the division Line, between the Lots 16, and 17. in Square No 253, in the City of Washington. The City Surveyor, had already, surveyed and marked out, the division line of which he had given, a plat to Dr. Miller, by which was certified, that my brick stable erected in the year 1821, encroaches, fourteen inches, on the Lot, Number 17. now belonging to Dr. Miller; but which belonged, when my Stable was erected to Dr. William Thornton; and my Stable, was built immediately adjoining to the stable already standing on the Land of Dr. Thornton and placed immediately bordering, upon his boundary— I complained, that this admeasurement had been made by the City Surveyor, for Dr. Miller, without previous notice, given to me— I doubted its legality; and before submitting to it, took time for examining the City, Laws, relating to the powers of the City Surveyor, and the division lines between proprieties of adjoining buildings— Capt Casey and his
sister paid us a morning visit—

I examined this morning the Laws of the Corporation of the City of Washington to the end of the 30th. Council June 1833. with an appendix, containing Laws of the United States relating to the City, by Andrew Rathbun— In page 209 of this Book, I found an Act authorizing the appointment of a Surveyor of the City of Washington and establishing a Surveyors Office therein and in page 384, of the same Volume an Act authorizing the proprietors, of Squares and Lots in the City of Washington to have the same subdivided and admitted to Record— These two acts, contain the Laws, by which, the present City Surveyor, and Dr. Miller, have proceeded in the Survey, of the division line, between the Lot 16. belonging to me, and the Lot 17. which belongs partly to Dr. Miller. I called on Mr. Frye, at his Office, and referred him to these two Laws, requesting him to examine, the Plat of the City of Washington, and laid down under the Act of Congress, and recorded, the 4th. of October 1792— Mr. Frye did accordingly, examine the Plat of the City and obtain from the surveyor’s Officer, a certified Copy, of the Square Number 253. He took with him this copy and gave it to me certified by two witnesses himself, and Col Moore— I consulted with Mr. Frye, what I should further do, to secure my own property and I concluded, to have a regular Survey, and Plot, of the two Lots, Number 8. and 16, in Square 253, made by the City Surveyor and a Plot thereof, duly authenticated to ascertain, the Bounds of my own property—and so far as relates, to the encroachment, of my brick Stable, upon the lot Number 17. to abide by the Law, as specially prescribed, in the act, in page 384, of Rothwell’s, edition
of the Laws of the Corporation of the City in the fourth section of which it is especially provided for— We took a ride this afternoon, and had evening visits, first from Mr. & Mrs. Robert Greenhow, and afterwards from Mrs. Madison and Miss Payne—

A nearly sleepless, and very uncomfortable night— My Granddaughter Mary Louisa who has been three days on a visit to Mrs. Turnbull returned home—and my Nephew Lieutenant Joseph Harrod Adams, left us for New York— Mr. Frye, was here this morng. and has left with me, an authenticated copy of Square Number 253, as laid down, by the Commissioners of the City and recorded on the 4th. of October 1792. In the agreement between the Commissioners and David Burns, the original Proprietor of this Square. the Lot Number, 8, was assigned, to the Public and the Lot Number 16. would remain to the said David Burns— Mr. Frye will apply to the City Surveyor, for a new Survey of the Lots number 8. and 16. I had some conversation last evening, with Mr. Greenhow, concerning, the expedition of St Dennis, to Mexico, in 1715, and he sent me today, an Article published by him, in the New Orleans Commercial Review of October 1846, and of the New York Evening Post of November 13th.: of the same year with some additional Manuscript notes, all of which are parts, of an unpublished History of Florida, Louisiana, and Texas, by him. In this Article, there is much information, respecting the controvert title to Texas, between France and Spain from its origin—

Mr. Frye, called and left with me, an exact authenticated copy by the City Surveyor Randolph Coyle of a record of Square No 253. on North F. and G. Streets.
of the original Plan of the City of Washington made and certified by the Commissioners, on the 4th. day of October 1792— He also wrote me this day a note, stating that Colonel William Brent the Clerk of the Circuit Court, had promised him yesterday, copies of the Deeds, from David Burns, of Lots No 8 and 16 square No two-hundred and fifty three and that the Surveyor of the City had promised to re-survey the Plot, of Lots No 8 and 16, next Tuesday— I received another Note from Mr. Frye, delivered to me by Alexander Borland whom he recommends, as a Carpenter to contract, for repairing the Stable— I visited the Observatory, and saw the West Transit Instruments, the Prime Vertical Instrument, theCircle, the Meridian Circle and the Equatorial— There is another Instrument, called the Refraction Circle ordered, to be made by Ertel at Munich but which has not yet arrived. In the Appendix to the Volume of Astronomical Observations presented me by Lieut M. F. Maury, there is at page 14, a List, of fifteen Officers besides himself attached to the Office. for all its duties of observation and computationone of these is Mr. Sears. C. Walker—between whom and the Superintendent Maury, there appears to be some misunderstanding— In the National Intelligencer of yesterday there was an Article, from Mr. Maury, dated from the Observatory though not signed and an Article this morng signed by Mr. Walker concerning which I spoke to Mr. Maury, with regret as indicating some dissension between them— Mr. Walker complains that he was the person who made the discovery that Lalande the French Astronomer had actually observed in March 1795. as a fixed Star, the recently discovered Planet Neptune—and that Mr. Maury in announcing this fact, had not specially named him Walker, as the person who had first ascertained and announced this fact. Mr. Maury, disclaims any intention of injustice, to Mr. Walker, whose
seems to me unreasonable; But the discovery of this New Planet Neptune has led to wonderful excitement among the Astronomers of Europe, and of America, pleasingly indicative of the intense interest, taken in the pursuit of Astronomical Science

At the Unitarian Church this morning where I attended with Elizabeth. C. Adams, Mr. Bellows, preached from Matthew 5.44. “But I say unto you, love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them that despitefully use you, and persecute you.” In the afternoon, at St John’s Church, Mr. . . . read the evening Service for Whitsunday and preached from 1. Corinthians, 15–20— “But now is Christ risen from the dead and become the first fruits, of them that slept”— A discourse, upon the immortality of man, able, and eloquent, but not so forcible, as I should have desired— In the evening, Isaac Hull Adams, and Lieutenant Thom were here—

I received this morning a Letter from Mrs. Catherine, Maria Frances Smith, with an Order, which she had forgotten to sign, to my Son Charles. Francis Adams, Trustee of T. B. Johnsons Will, to pay me on my order, the sum of one hundred and thirty five dollars advanced to her, this day— For which I gave her a check on the Bank of the Metropolis for thirty five dollars, in addition to that for one hundred dollars which I gave her on the 15th. inst— This Order, I enclosed in a Letter to my son which I forwarded to him this day— I took a ride this evening—and at night we had visits, from Mr. & Mrs. Campbell, Mrs. Key, Miss Ringgold, Dr. Ringgold, Isaac Hull Adams and Lieut Thom—
